newsitem.title: USA: National parks bill stalls in U.S. Senate.
newsitem.headline: National parks bill stalls in U.S. Senate.

text.p: The White House Wednesday threatened to veto a bill to help raise funds for national parks, complaining the package agreed to by House and Senate conferees would hurt parks and a national forest in Alaska.

Most environmental groups also opposed the bill because it would let the government license corporations to become national parks sponsors and use that in their advertising, a move that critics said would cheapen and commercialize the national treasures.

While the administration had backed corporate sponsorship as a way to help pay for the parks' staggering backlog of repairs, the plan came under increasing fire and was the target of a number of advertisements and editorials.

Eleven Senate Democrats in a letter Wednesday slammed the bill, saying it would introduce "commercialism into one of America's last non-commercial refuges" while raising a tiny fraction of money the parks need.
But backers argued it was an essential tool to raise money, and said the bill had safeguards to prevent businesses from exploiting and commercializing the parks.
The White House did not mention the corporate sponsorship plan in its veto threat, but cited several other complaints.

Those included a plan to continue a logging company's exclusive contract for timber in Alaska's Tongass National Forest, boundary changes in a few parks, erosion of coastal barrier island protections in Florida and changes in regulating rights-of-way across federal lands.

The bill, loaded with projects in some 41 states, also would have let the financially-troubled parks raise entrance fees, create five parks, and set up a trust fund to manage San Fransisco's Presidio national park.

"We contacted the White House and asked for their views. We took out some controversial measures," said an aide to House Resources Committee Chairman Don Young, an Alaska Republican who was one of the bill's sponsors.

"Now it seems like the president wants to kill the whole thing. So if that's what he wants to do he kills the whole package," said the aide, who said there were no plans to spin off parts of the bill into other legislation.

"The administration's letter is full of factual errors and appears to be based on the false hope any related bills will move separate from the conference report," Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee Chairman Frank Murkowski, also an Alaska Republican, said in a statement.
"They had better do their homework and get back to me in the morning," Murkowski said.
One of the measures conferees dropped would have extended for 15 years an exclusive contract held by the Ketchikan Pulp Co for timber in Alaska's Tongass National Forest.
But the bill would have transferred eight remaining years of the pulp mill's exclusive contract to Ketchikan's sawmills, which environmentalists and the White House also opposed.
